channel.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

image.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition

channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Europe risks botching its big plans to rescue the economy
Europe slowly reopens as WHO chief warns: 'There can be no going back to business as usual'
Sweden was supposed to remind me of 'normal' but instead felt reckless
item.description: The motto that runs through the veins of CNN producers and reporters is "Go There." Yet coronavirus has turned "going there" from normal to abnormal.

item.title: Trump visits face mask factory, doesn't wear a mask
item.description: President Trump was seen not wearing a face mask during his visit to the Honeywell factory in Arizona, which manufactures N95 masks.

item.title: Why Tuesday was the most important (and scary) day of America's coronavirus fight so far
Trump claims the coronavirus was made in this lab. Here are the facts
Woman jailed for opening salon amid lockdown. See what she told judge.
item.description: Dallas salon owner Shelly Luther was sentenced to 7 days in jail after refusing to close her salon despite statewide stay-at-home orders.

item.title: Three Marines step in to restrain unruly passenger on flight from Japan
item.description: Three US Marines stepped in to detain a passenger who allegedly made threatening comments during a flight from Japan to Texas.

item.title: Professor researching Covid-19 was killed in an apparent murder-suicide, officials say
item.description: A University of Pittsburgh professor on the verge of making "very significant findings" researching Covid-19, according to the university, was shot and killed in an apparent murder-suicide over the weekend, police said.

item.title: Doctor denied green card while treating Covid-19 patients: 'Like a slap in the face'
item.description: Dr. Julia Iafrate is a sponsored immigrant volunteering to help save the lives of coronavirus patients in the ICU, and says she was denied a green card despite her extensive credentials. CNN's Chris Cuomo speaks with her about her experience.

item.title: Transcripts of closed-door interviews from Russia probe may finally be released
item.description: More than two years after the House Intelligence Committee ended its investigation into Russia's 2016 election interference, the transcripts of the committee's interviews with more than four dozen witnesses could be publicly released soon.

item.title: Major broadcaster regularly criticized by Duterte forced off air
item.description: One of the Philippines largest and most influential broadcasting networks has been forced off the air after lawmakers allied with President Rodrigo Duterte sat on a decision to renew the station's license. The move was condemned by critics as an attack on the country's free press.

item.title: Astronomers find the closest black hole to Earth
item.description: A black hole has been discovered 1,000 light-years from Earth, making it the closest black hole to our solar system ever found.

item.title: Widow calls killing of security guard for telling customer to wear face mask 'senseless and stupid'
item.description: Calvin Munerlyn, the security guard who was shot and killed in Michigan last week, was "loved everywhere," his widow told CNN.

item.title: See video Russian doctor filmed before he mysteriously fell from window
item.description: Three frontline health care workers have mysteriously fallen out of hospital windows in Russia over the past two weeks, heightening public attention to the working conditions for doctors and medical professionals amid the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: 5-year-old who started driving to California to buy a Lamborghini finally got to ride in one
item.description: The gutsy 5-year-old who took his parents' car with $3 in his pocket and a dream to buy a Lamborghini finally got to ride in the luxury sports car. This time, though, he wasn't driving.

item.title: Chastened Samsung heir will not hand the company down to his children
item.description: Samsung's de facto leader Lee Jae-yong says he will not be handing the company's management over to his children.

item.title: X Æ A-12: Grimes explains the name of her son with Elon Musk
item.description: Singer Grimes has revealed the meaning behind the unique name of her newborn son with Tesla and SpaceX CEO, Elon Musk.

item.title: Someone flushed a toilet during the US Supreme Court's oral arguments
item.description: Well, someone forgot to mute.

item.title: Atlanta mayor reacts to packed streets on Cinco de Mayo
item.description: Atlanta Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms reacts to images showing crowds of people outside celebrating Cinco de Mayo, saying it's "disappointing" and that coronavirus "is still a deadly virus."

item.title: Minor League Baseball pitcher found out his family was killed over Facebook
item.description: Minor League Baseball player Blake Bivens says he learned his wife, young son and mother-in-law had been killed when he read the news on Facebook last year.

item.title: The machines helping hospitals fight coronavirus
item.description: Intensive care units around the word are caring for patients with Covid-19, this is the equipment medical workers need to treat one severe patient.

item.title: How to improve your respiratory health in case you get Covid-19
Meghan reads from 'Duck! Rabbit!' to celebrate son Archie's first birthday
item.description: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex has celebrated her son Archie's first birthday with a reading of the children's book "Duck! Rabbit!," as she and Prince Harry launched an effort to help children affected by the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus is killing more African Americans than any other group in the US, study finds
item.description: More African Americans are dying from coronavirus in the United States than whites or other ethnic groups, according to a new study .

item.title: Journalist warned of the virus decades ago. Hear her best case for how it ends.
item.description: Journalist and author Laurie Garrett discusses how the coronavirus pandemic could end.

item.title: Adele lost weight, are we allowed to praise that?
item.description: Adele has always loved the skin she is in.

item.title: Jessica Simpson says she felt body-shamed by Vogue
item.description: Jessica Simpson was not happy about a story Vogue shared about her, and the publication has apologized.

item.title: See testing units in Israel designed for zero exposure
item.description: Israel has developed mobile Covid-19 testing units which allow the testers to swab individuals without the ​risk of exposure to the virus. CNN's Oren Liebermann tried them out.

item.title: Michelle Obama opens up in revealing new documentary
item.description: Michelle Obama has been away from the White House for more than three years, a period long enough to write a memoir and release an accompanying documentary film.

item.title: How your passwords can end up for sale on the dark web
item.description: Last month, Zoom joined a long list of companies whose user data has fallen prey to hackers. More than half a million account logins for the hugely popular video conferencing platform were discovered on the dark web, either offered for free or for next to nothing.

item.title: Covid-19 could spell economic disaster for idyllic island
item.description: Spain's Formentera island is being allowed to reopen a week ahead of the rest of the country. But while it managed to largely avoid Covid-19, Formentera's tourism-based economy will struggle. CNN's Scott McLean reports.

item.title: Explore Le Corbusier's modernist Indian metropolis
item.description: Photographer Roberto Conte uncovers the hidden gems of Chandigarh, in a new series exploring the Le Corbusier-designed Indian city.

item.title: Arctic dinosaur may have crossed from America to Asia to dominate the north
item.description: Long before early humans crossed the land bridge that used to link Asia and America, an "incredibly successful" duck-billed dinosaur may have trodden the same path, allowing it to dominate northern latitudes of the world 70 million years ago.

item.title: China takes step towards space station with new rocket launch
item.description: China's latest large carrier rocket made its first successful flight Tuesday, an important step in the nation's plan to build a space station, according to state-run news agency Xinhua.

item.title: The ghost stations hidden beneath London
item.description: Thanks to its complex history, London has long been associated with ghosts.

item.title: Dad freaks out over 4-year-old son's first home run
item.description: A Georgia dad jumped in the air with excitement after his four-year-old son hit his first home run.

item.title: The inspiring tale of an overlooked female designer who helped define mid-century modern style
item.description: In November of 1938, when Ruth Adler Schnee was 15 years old, Nazi soldiers smashed the windows of her family home in Dusseldorf, Germany. They wrenched the doors off their hinges, shattered the Limoges china and threw the Biedermeier furniture out the window, as part of a violent campaign targeting Jewish families in the prologue to the Holocaust.

item.title: With nowhere to go we're spending less on makeup -- but we're still pampering
item.description: Like so many of our regular habits, our morning grooming regimes may have changed because of the pandemic. A daily shave, applying a full face of make-up, dousing yourself in a heady spritz of your favorite scent, or working layers of product through your hair might feel a little over the top for those living under strict lockdown.

item.title: Watch Daniel Radcliffe read 'Harry Potter'
item.description: Daniel Radcliffe and other celebrities are taking turns reading chapters of the "Harry Potter" book series, as part of J.K. Rowling's new online reading hub.

item.title: Vanessa Bryant opens 'one more letter' from Kobe on her birthday
item.description: Vanessa Bryant waited one more day to open the surprise she never expected, never knew existed.

item.title: Vivid hues in your home can lift your mood
item.description: How do colors make us feel? This question has guided color specialist Leatrice Eiseman since childhood. As the executive director of the Pantone Color Institute, she leads color trends and forecasts as well as the decision-making behind the company's annual Color of the Year (the choice for 2020, Classic Blue, is proving to be an apt calming color for an already anxious year.)

item.title: The world's most epic scuba diving destinations
item.description: If only salt water -- sweat, tears and the sea -- really was the cure for everything, as Danish author Isak Dinesen once said. Then scuba diving would be just the antidote the world needed right now.

item.title: A spa of one's own
item.description: Remember hotel spas, with their serene settings, lavish amenities and pampering treatments? The way a luxurious relaxing experience provided an escape from the stresses of everyday life?

item.title: How an Olympic champion is observing Ramadan during the pandemic
item.description: The holy month of Ramadan is usually a time for families and friends to come together, but the coronavirus pandemic has changed everything.

item.title: Recovery jeopardized by reopening of old political and legal wounds that could threaten trillions of euros
item.description: Europe's ability to recover from the worst economic shock it has seen since the Great Depression is being jeopardized by the reopening of old political and legal wounds that could threaten trillions of euros in stimulus money.

item.title: Germany sets out reopening plan with limits on social contact
item.description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel set out plans Wednesday for the gradual reopening of the country after weeks-long restrictions imposed to stem the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: Trump says China could have stopped pandemic
How 39 million Europeans kept their jobs after the work dried up
item.description: In Europe, nearly 39 million people are being paid by governments to work part time or not at all, a record level of support that will shape the region's ability to claw its way out of the deep recession triggered by the coronavirus.

item.title: See Trump's reaction when nurse says she lacks PPE
item.description: President Donald Trump disagreed with a nurse he was honoring in the Oval Office, insisting that he hadn't heard about personal protective equipment shortages in the US despite her account that PPE availability is "sporadic."
